ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chamber music repertoire and interpersonal skills
Developed skills in chamber music, performance, and group work. Learned Beethoven Op. 59 No. 3.
I developed greater collaboration skills by working closely with the same group all semester. We practiced time management, rehearsal skills, and supporting each other as a team.
I learned about rehearsal and performance techniques in a quartet setting.
Performance of chamber music and rehearsal techniques
Playing chamber music at a high level, interpretation of chamber music, working with coaches. Listening to others' performances critically and providing feedback.
I learned a great deal about chamber music.
Good structure for preparation of an entire major chamber work - coaching, performance class helped to push process along
I learned how to be a better chamber musician, through coachings and studio class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class is excellent and very fun and instructional!

Strengths: well supported model of teaching, lots of independent work. 

Weaknesses: coaches often give conflicting advice, classes often run over, experience largely dependent on the other people in your chamber group, their attitude and work ethic.
I enjoyed the structure of having class every two weeks so that we were given enough time to rehearse, but also the chance to practice performing each movement of our selection.

I think this class is wonderful in that we are able to play chamber music at a high level at an undergraduate university.  I would love it if Wendy could hire at least one coach who is of color (there are great quartets out there who are people of color), making the class a more inclusive space.  I think she should also hire coaches who have lots of experience teaching chamber music.  One of my coaches this year really did not seem to have their heart into coaching my group, and I feel like we did not receive helpful feedback-- my experience in the past with other coaches were much more exciting.  The class could also be expanded into two periods-- I feel like this class could include a lot more people-- I know many other hard-working students who love to play music just as much as I do who did not get into the class, and I think it would be more fun to have the class be less competitive to get into!
The class is a very supportive environment to practice performing. It is also a great opportunity to be able to work with the coaches from the Callisto Quartet.
It was perfect.
More performance opportunities along the way outside of class might be beneficial

This course offers a great exposure to a range of chamber music, especially if taken repeatedly. I think the course could benefit from increasing the diversity of its repertoire by including more contemporary composers.

This course is tailored to very serious musicians. While it gives players experience playing chamber music, I did not feel that we were given the general skills of being a good chamber musician. I would have like a lecture or two on things like cuing, listening to other players and tuning to them, and how to have effective rehearsals.

I understand that this class is billed as a Western canon class in contrast to the likes of MUSI 238, but would love to see a more diverse selection of repertoire (even within the same style/era as the Beethovens and Brahms etc. works that are historically central to the class)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This class is so fun!
No. Wendy Sharp is racist, transphobic, and generally awful. Please do not take this class if she is still teaching it.
Yes, but be aware that it is a BIG time commitment for only 0.5 credits.
Chamber music is love, chamber music is life.
Yes, to anyone who loves chamber music and wants to learn an entire piece in one semester.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student because I grew a lot as a chamber musician and also as a listener through giving feedback during class.
Yes, it is exciting to play chamber music with your peers for credit.
I would definitely recommend chamber music to another student. It was my favorite class this semester.
Yes, chamber music is the most rewarding form of music and Wendy is great.
Yes.  I learned how to work very well with other students.
Yes, great opportunity for undergrad chamber music
I would recommend this class to anyone wanting to pursue chamber music at a high level and put in a significant amount of rehearsal time.

Yes! This is an awesome course for a musician who wants to do serious chamber music as an undergraduate at Yale. However, there are not many wind players in the class, and spots for strings and piano are very competitive.
